The use, distribution or reproduction in other forums is permitted, provided the original author(s) and the copyright owner(s) are credited and that the original publication in this journal is cited, in accordance with accepted academic practice. No use, distribution or reproduction is permitted which does not comply with these terms. Oxidative stress, one of the primary pathogenic factors in neurodegenerative diseases, plays a key role in neuronal damage via various apoptotic mechanisms. Using natural antioxidants to counteract oxidative stress may be a useful approach to slow the progression of neurodegenerative diseases. Licochalcone D (LCD), a root extract of Glycyrrhiza inflata 2 2 2 2 βIII-tubulin GAP43 Nestin MAP2 2 2 2 2 apoptosis licochalcone D neurotoxicity oxidative stress reactive oxygen species Korea Institute of Toxicology 10.13039/501100003705 Korea Environmental Industry and Technology Institute 10.13039/501100003654 The author(s) declare that financial support was received for the research and/or publication of this article. pmc-prop-suppress-copyright no pmc-prop-is-real-version no pmc-prop-is-scanned-article no pmc-prop-preprint no pmc-prop-in-epmc yes section-at-acceptance Ethnopharmacology 1 Introduction Oxidative stress due to excessive reactive oxygen species (ROS) levels, a primary cause of nerve damage, contributes to the development of neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer’s Disease, Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis, Huntington’s Disease, Parkinson’s Disease, and stroke ( Ashok et al., 2022 Zhang et al., 2020 Jeong et al., 2021 A small but significant portion of oxygen, approximately 4%–5%, undergoes conversion to ROS via biological reducing agents in the human body ( Jomova et al., 2023 2 2 − Smith et al., 2022 Jomova et al., 2023 Jiang et al., 2022 Jomova et al., 2023 Ashok et al., 2022 2 2 Park, 2013 Tochigi et al., 2013 − Kumar et al., 2023 2 2 Jeong et al., 2021 Ashok et al., 2022 Licorice is a traditional herbal medicine commonly used in East Asia for the treatment of various diseases ( Jiang et al., 2020 Zhou et al., 2017 Glycyrrhiza inflata Maharajan et al., 2021 Deng et al., 2023 Deng et al., 2023 Maharajan et al., 2021 2 2 in vitro 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials and reagents The reagents and materials were sourced as follows: Dulbecco’s Modified Eagle’s Medium (DMEM), trypsin/EDTA, fetal bovine serum (FBS), and penicillin/streptomycin from Gibco (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Inc., Waltham, MA, United States); phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) from Corning (Corning, NY, United States); N-Acetyl-L-cysteine (NAC), retinoic acid (RA), and dimethyl sulfoxide from Sigma-Aldrich (St. Louis, MO, United States); 4′,6-diamidino-2-phenylindole (DAPI) from Invitrogen (Thermo Fisher Scientific); anti-βIII-tubulin primary antibody from Abcam (Cambridge, United Kingdom); the Cell Counting Kit-8 from Dojindo (Kumamoto, Japan); the CytoTox 96 non-radioactive cytotoxicity assay kit and BCA Protein Assay Kit from Promega (Madison, WI, United States); RIPA lysis buffer from Rockland Immunochemicals (Limerick, PA, United States); and LCD (99.95% purity) from Selleckchem (Houston, TX, United States). 2.2 Cell culture, differentiation, and treatments The SH-SY5Y human neuroblastoma cell line was obtained from the Korean Cell Bank (Seoul, Republic of Korea). The cells were cultured for 24 h in DMEM supplemented with growth medium (10% FBS and 1% penicillin/streptomycin) in a 37 °C humidified atmosphere containing 5% CO 2 2 2. 2.3 Cell counting Kit-8 (CCK-8) assay Cell viability was assessed using a CCK-8 assay (Dojindo). SH-SY5Y cells (3.5 × 10 4 2 2 2 2.4 Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) assay Cytotoxicity was evaluated by measuring LDH release from the cytoplasm into the culture medium upon plasma-membrane damage. The cells were plated at 3.5 × 10 4 2 2 2.5 Detection of intracellular ROS Intracellular ROS activity was assessed using the cell-permeating fluorescent redox probe 2′,7′-dichlorofluorescein diacetate (DCFH-DA). The cells were seeded in 96-well plates at a density of 3.5 × 10 4 2 2 2.6 Analysis of mitochondrial membrane potential Mitochondrial function was assessed by monitoring mitochondrial membrane potential using a fluorescent dye, 5,5′,6,6′-tetrachloro-1,1′,3,3′-tetraethylbenzimidazol-carbocyanine iodide (JC-1; Invitrogen). The cells were pretreated without LCD (control or H 2 2 2 2 2.7 Quantification of intracellular ATP Intracellular ATP levels were measured using the ATP Assay Kit (ab83355; Abcam), which employs a fluorometric enzymatic reaction to quantify ATP via phosphorylation of glycerol. For reagent preparation, Converter Mix B and Developer Mix N were each dissolved in 220 µL Buffer 23 and kept on ice. A 0.1 mM ATP standard was freshly prepared from a 10 mM stock and serially diluted (0–10 µL) in Buffer 23 to a final volume of 50 µL per well. Cells were harvested, washed with cold PBS, lysed in 100 µL Buffer 23 by pipetting, and centrifuged at 13,000 × g for 5 min at 4 °C; the supernatants were used for analysis. For each well, 1–50 µL of cell extract was adjusted to 50 µL with Buffer 23, followed by addition of 50 µL ATP reaction mix. Control reactions lacking Converter Mix B were included to assess background. After 30 min incubation at room temperature in the dark, fluorescence was measured at 535/587 nm. 2.8 RNA isolation, cDNA synthesis, and real-time qPCR Cells were seeded in 100 mm cell culture plates at 4 × 10 6 2 2 Table 1 TUBB3 NES GAP43 MAP2 −ΔΔCT Livak and Schmittgen, 2001 β-actin TABLE 1 List of qRT-PCR primers. Gene Forward primer Reverse primer  Nestin AAC​AGC​GAC​GGA​GGT​CTC​TA TTC​TCT​TGT​CCC​GCA​GAC​TT  βⅢ-tubulin CAT​CCA​GAG​CAA​GAA​CAG​CA CTC​GGT​GAA​CTC​CAT​CTC​GT  GAP43 AGG​GAG​AAG​GCA​CCA​CTA​CT GGA​GGA​CGG​CGA​GTT​ATC​AG  MAP2 TGCCATCTTGGTGCCGA CTT​GAC​ATT​ACC​ACC​TCC​AGG​T  β-actin CAT​GTA​CGT​TGC​TAT​CCA​GGC CTC​CTT​AAT​GTC​ACG​CAC​GAT 2.9 Neurite outgrowth assessment using high-content analysis Cells were fixed in 4% formaldehyde in PBS for 10–15 min, and then washed three times with PBS. Permeabilization was performed using PBS containing 0.1% Triton X-100 for 15 min at room temperature. To prevent nonspecific binding, the cells were blocked for 1 h in PBS containing 10% FBS and 0.1% bovine serum albumin. They were then incubated overnight at 4 °C with the primary antibody, anti-βIII-tubulin, diluted in PBS with 0.1% Tween-20. After washing with PBS containing 0.1% Tween-20, the cells were incubated for 1 h with an Alexa Fluor 488-conjugated secondary antibody (Abcam) and 0.5 μg/mL DAPI (Invitrogen) in PBS containing 0.1% Tween-20. Fluorescence intensity was measured using the Operetta CLS High-Content Imaging System (PerkinElmer, Waltham, MA, United States) with a ×20 confocal objective. Images were analyzed using Harmony 6.1, which provides various modules for assessing neurite outgrowth. 2.10 Western blotting The cells were lysed using RIPA buffer (Rockland Immunochemicals) supplemented with a protease and phosphatase inhibitor cocktail (Cell Signaling Technology, Danvers, MA, United States). Protein concentrations were determined using a BCA assay. For analysis, 20–40 μg of protein per lane was subjected to electrophoresis on 8%, 12%, or 15% SDS-PAGE gels, followed by transfer onto polyvinylidene difluoride membranes (Millipore, Bedford, MA, United States). The membranes were blocked with 3% skim milk in PBS containing 1% Tween 20 for 1–2 h at room temperature, and then incubated overnight at 4 °C with primary antibodies targeting Bax (sc-7480), Bcl-2 (sc-7382), caspase-3 (sc-56053), caspase-7 (sc-56063), GAPDH (sc-47742), PARP-1 (sc-8007), p38 (#9212), or p-p38 (#4511), all diluted 1:1000. After washing with PBS containing 1% Tween-20, the membranes were treated with HRP-conjugated secondary antibodies (goat anti-rabbit IgG-HRP or goat anti-mouse IgG-HRP) for 2 h at room temperature. Detection was performed using the WesternBright ECL substrate (Advansta, San Jose, CA, United States). Images were captured using the ChemiDoc XRS+ imaging system (Bio-Rad Laboratories). 2.11 Statistical analysis The results are expressed as the mean ± standard error of the mean (SEM), derived from three or more independent experiments. Analyses were performed using SPSS 12 (IBM Corp., Armonk, NY, United States) for Windows. Statistical significance was assessed using one-way ANOVA, followed by Dunnett’s post hoc p 3 Results 3.1 LCD protects SH-SY5Y cells against H 2 2 SH-SY5Y cell growth and proliferation and LCD cytotoxicity were measured and evaluated qualitatively using CCK-8 and LDH assays. LCD did not alter cell viability ( Figure 1A 2 2 2 2 Figure 1B 2 2 50 2 2 50 Supplementary Figure S1 2 2 Figure 1C 2 2 Figure 1D 2 2 Figure 1D 2 2 2 2 Figure 1E FIGURE 1 Inhibitive effects of LCD on H 2 2 2 2 (A–C) n (D) (E) 2 2 n p p ### p 2 2 Graphs and images analyze cell viability and cytotoxicity impacted by LCD and H₂O₂. (A) Graph shows cell viability under varying LCD concentrations. (B) Graph illustrates H₂O₂’s effect, with IC₅₀ marked. (C) and (D) Graphs compare cells treated with H₂O₂ and different LCD doses on viability and cytotoxicity, with significance indicated. (E) Microscopic images depict cell morphology under various treatments. 3.2 LCD exhibits neuroprotective effects against H 2 2 To assess the neuroprotective effects of LCD, neurite outgrowth was measured using a high-content screening device. At a non-cytotoxic H 2 2 Figure 1B Figure 2B 2 2 Figure 2B 2 2 Figure 2C Figure 1 2 2 Figure 2C FIGURE 2 Protective effects of LCD against neurotoxicity following exposure of SH-SY5Y cells to H 2 2 2 2 (A) (B,C) N p ## p ### p 2 2 Cell culture images and bar graphs depict the effect of different concentrations of LCD and H₂O₂. Panel A shows merged and magnified fluorescence images of neuronal cells treated with various LCD and H₂O₂ levels. Panels B and C display bar graphs comparing the percentage of control for the number of cells and total neurite length under different conditions. The graphs illustrate how varying concentrations impact cellular morphology and growth, with statistical significance indicated by symbols. We investigated four genes directly associated with neural differentiation, development, and neurite outgrowth ( βIII-tubulin GAP43 Nestin MAP2 2 2 Figure 3 βIII-tubulin GAP43 2 2 2 2 βIII-tubulin GAP43 NES MAP2 FIGURE 3 Impacts of LCD on neurodevelopmental genes in differentiated SH-SY5Y cells with H 2 2 βIII-tubulin GAP43 Nestin MAP2 N p # p ### p 2 2 Bar graph showing the fold change of four genes: beta III-tubulin, GAP43, Nestin, and MAP2 under different treatments. Treatments include control, LCD at different concentrations, hydrogen peroxide, and combinations of both. Significant changes are indicated with asterisks and hash symbols, showing varying levels of protein expression, with Nestin and MAP2 showing notable differences under certain conditions. 3.3 NAC mitigates H 2 2 To assess whether the H 2 2 2 2 Figure 4A 2 2 2 2 Figure 4A 2 2 Figure 4B 2 2 Figure 4B Figure 4C 2 2 Figure 4C Supplementary Figure S2 FIGURE 4 Effects of NAC and LCD pretreatment on the H 2 2 2 2 (A) (B) (C) 2 2 (D) n p p p ## p ### p 2 2 Four-panel scientific figure. (A) Bar graph showing cell viability percentages with different treatments, highlighting the effect of NAC and hydrogen peroxide. (B) Bar graph detailing cell cytotoxicity percentages, showing changes due to NAC, hydrogen peroxide, and lysis buffer. (C) Bar graph on DCF fluorescence, demonstrating various concentrations of LCD, NAC, TBHP, and hydrogen peroxide treatments. (D) Series of fluorescence micrographs showing DCFH-DA staining under different conditions, including control, LCD, H₂O₂, and NAC, illustrating differences in fluorescence intensity. Oxidative-stress-induced mitochondrial dysfunction is an important factor in neurodegenerative disorders ( Ashok et al., 2022 Jiang et al., 2022 2 2 2 2 Figures 5A,B 2 2 2 2 2 2 Figure 5C 2 2 2 2 Figure 4C Figure 4C 2 2 2 2 2 2 2 2 Figures 6A,B 2 2 2 2 2 2 Figures 6A,B FIGURE 5 Mitigation of H 2 2 2 2 (A) (B) n (C) n p p ## p ### p 2 2 Fluorescent microscopy images and bar graphs examining the effect of various treatments on mitochondrial membrane potential and ATP production. Panel A shows three rows of images: 1. JC-1 aggregate fluorescence in red.2. JC-1 monomer fluorescence in green.3. Merged images with both red and green signals. The columns represent different treatments: Control, \(H_2O_2\), \(H_2O_2 + \text{LCD}\), \(H_2O_2 + \text{NAC}\), and CCCP. Panel B shows a bar graph of the JC-1 aggregate/monomer ratio for each treatment. Panel C shows a bar graph of ATP production levels under varying treatments. Scale bars and statistical significance markers are included. FIGURE 6 Effects of NAC on neurite outgrowth in differentiated SH-SY5Y cells pretreated with H 2 2 2 2 (A) (B) n N p p # p ## p 2 2 A. Fluorescence Microscopy images of cells under different treatments: NAC and H₂O₂. merged and magnified views showing cell nuclei and neurite outgrowth. B. Bar graph comparing number of cells and total neurite length under the same conditions, represented as percentages. Different bars indicate statistical significance. 3.4 LCD inhibits H 2 2 To evaluate the underlying mechanisms of action of LCD, we quantified the expression of H 2 2 2 2 Figures 7A,B 2 2 Figures 7A,C Figures 7A,D 2 2 Figures 7A,C Figures 7A,D 2 2 Figures 7A,E 2 2 FIGURE 7 Western blotting was performed to quantify apoptosis-related protein expression in SH-SY5Y cells. (A) (B–E) N p p p # p ### p 2 2 Western blot image illustrating protein expression levels and bar graphs showing protein/GAPDH ratios. Panel A displays bands for proteins: p-p38, p38, Bax, Bcl-2, pro-caspase 3, and GAPDH, under different LCD and H2O2 concentrations. Panels B to E provide bar graphs comparing the ratios of p-p38, Bax, Bcl-2, and caspase-3 to GAPDH under the same conditions, indicating significant changes marked by asterisks and hashes. 4 Discussion Using SH-SY5Y cells, we examined the neuroprotective effects of LCD and its potential mechanisms of action in mitigating H 2 2 Figure 1A Maharajan et al., 2021 2 2 2 2 Figure 1B 2 2 Figure 1C The developing nervous system is highly sensitive to the influence of various chemicals ( Crofton et al., 2012 in vitro Radio and Mundy, 2008 Shipley et al., 2016 Ryan et al., 2016 2 2 Figure 2 2 2 The observed reduction in neurite length indicates inhibition of neurodevelopment and altered expression of the related genes ( Oh et al., 2022 βIII-tubulin Jiang and Oblinger, 1992 Nestin Deng and Poretz, 2003 MAP2 Dehmelt and Halpain, 2005 GAP43 Chung et al., 2020 2 2 βIII-tubulin Nestin MAP2 GAP43 Figure 3 Reese and Drapeau, 1998 Fauth and Tetzlaff, 2016 Yacoub et al., 2025 in vitro Pardridge, 2012 Choudhari et al., 2021 2 2 Figure 3 H 2 2 Chidawanyika and Supattapone, 2021 2 2 2 2 Figure 4A 2 2 Figure 4B 2 2 Figure 4C Redza-Dutordoir and Averill-Bates, 2016 2 2 Figure 5B Redza-Dutordoir and Averill-Bates, 2016 Collin, 2019 Ashok et al., 2022 2 2 Figure 6 Supplementary Figure S2 Macromolecules such as H 2 2 Chidawanyika and Supattapone, 2021 Tong et al., 2018 2 2 Figure 7B Carrington et al., 2017 Carrington et al., 2017 2 2 Figures 7C,D Redza-Dutordoir and Averill-Bates, 2016 2 2 Figure 7E 2 2 Oh et al., 2023 Figures 1C,D 4 2 2 Furusawa et al., 2009 Park et al., 2011 Park et al., 2015 Deng et al., 2023 Lee et al., 2025 in vitro in vivo Data availability statement The original contributions presented in the study are included in the article/ Supplementary Material Author contributions A-WK: Conceptualization, Formal Analysis, Methodology, Visualization, Writing – original draft. metadata.Title of this paper: Licorice extract attenuates brain aging of d-galactose induced rats through inhibition of oxidative stress and attenuation of neuronal apoptosis
